 25641     text.value = (unsigned char *) icon_name;
 25642     text.encoding = XA_STRING;
 25643     text.format = 8;
 25644     text.nitems = strlen (icon_name);
 25645     XSetWMIconName (FRAME_X_DISPLAY (f), FRAME_OUTER_WINDOW (f), &text);
 25646   }
 25647 
 25648   if (f->output_data.x->icon_bitmap > 0)
 25649     image_destroy_bitmap (f, f->output_data.x->icon_bitmap);
 25650   f->output_data.x->icon_bitmap = 0;
 25651   x_wm_set_icon_pixmap (f, 0);
 25652 
 25653   return false;
 25654 }
 25655 
 25656 
 25657 struct x_error_message_stack
 25658 {
 25659   /* Pointer to the error message of any error that was generated, or
 25660      NULL.  */
 25661   char *string;
 25662 
 25663   /* The display this error handler applies to.  */
 25664   Display *dpy;
 25665 
 25666   /* A function to call upon an error if non-NULL.  */
 25667   x_special_error_handler handler;
 25668 
 25669   /* Some data to pass to that handler function.  */
 25670   void *handler_data;
 25671 
 25672   /* The previous handler in this stack.  */
 25673   struct x_error_message_stack *prev;
 25674 
 25675   /* The first request that this error handler applies to.  Keeping
 25676      track of this allows us to avoid an XSync yet still have errors
 25677      for previously made requests be handled correctly.  */
 25678   unsigned long first_request;
 25679 };
 25680 
 25681 /* Stack of X error message handlers.  Whenever an error is generated
 25682    on a display, look in this stack for an appropriate error handler,
 25683    set its `string' to the error message and call its `handler' with
 25684    `handler_data'.  If no handler applies to the error, don't catch
 25685    it, and let it crash Emacs instead.
 25686 
 25687    This used to be a pointer to a string in which any error would be
 25688    placed before 2006.  */
 25689 static struct x_error_message_stack *x_error_message;
 25690 
 25691 /* The amount of items (depth) in that stack.  */
 25692 int x_error_message_count;
 25693 
 25694 /* Compare various request serials while handling wraparound.  Treat a
 25695    difference of more than X_ULONG_MAX / 2 as wraparound.
 25696 
 25697    Note that these functions truncate serials to 32 bits before
 25698    comparison.  */
 25699 
 25700 static bool
 25701 x_is_serial_more_than (unsigned int a, unsigned int b)
 25702 {
 25703   if (a > b)
 25704     return true;
 25705 
 25706   return (b - a > X_ULONG_MAX / 2);
 25707 }
 25708 
 25709 static bool
 25710 x_is_serial_more_than_or_equal_to (unsigned int a, unsigned int b)
 25711 {
 25712   if (a >= b)
 25713     return true;
 25714 
 25715   return (b - a > X_ULONG_MAX / 2);
 25716 }
 25717 
 25718 static bool
 25719 x_is_serial_less_than (unsigned int a, unsigned int b)
 25720 {
 25721   if (a < b)
 25722     return true;
 25723 
 25724   return (a - b > X_ULONG_MAX / 2);
 25725 }
 25726 
 25727 static bool
 25728 x_is_serial_less_than_or_equal_to (unsigned int a, unsigned int b)
 25729 {
 25730   if (a <= b)
 25731     return true;
 25732 
 25733   return (a - b > X_ULONG_MAX / 2);
 25734 }
 25735 
 25736 static struct x_error_message_stack *
 25737 x_find_error_handler (Display *dpy, XErrorEvent *event)
 25738 {
 25739   struct x_error_message_stack *stack;
 25740 
 25741   stack = x_error_message;
 25742 
 25743   while (stack)
 25744     {
 25745       if (x_is_serial_more_than_or_equal_to (event->serial,
 25746                                              stack->first_request)
 25747           && dpy == stack->dpy)
 25748         return stack;
 25749 
 25750       stack = stack->prev;
 25751     }
 25752 
 25753   return NULL;
 25754 }
 25755 
 25756 void
 25757 x_unwind_errors_to (int depth)
 25758 {
 25759   while (x_error_message_count > depth)
 25760     /* This is safe to call because we check whether or not
 25761        x_error_message->dpy is still alive before calling XSync.  */
 25762     x_uncatch_errors ();
 25763 }
 25764 
 25765 #define X_ERROR_MESSAGE_SIZE 200
 25766 
 25767 /* An X error handler which stores the error message in the first
 25768    applicable handler in the x_error_message stack.  This is called
 25769    from *x_error_handler if an x_catch_errors for DISPLAY is in
 25770    effect.  */
 25771 
 25772 static void
 25773 x_error_catcher (Display *display, XErrorEvent *event,
 25774                  struct x_error_message_stack *stack)
 25775 {
 25776   char buf[X_ERROR_MESSAGE_SIZE];
 25777 
 25778   XGetErrorText (display, event->error_code,
 25779                  buf, X_ERROR_MESSAGE_SIZE);
 25780 
 25781   if (stack->string)
 25782     xfree (stack->string);
 25783 
 25784   stack->string = xstrdup (buf);
 25785 
 25786   if (stack->handler)
 25787     stack->handler (display, event, stack->string,
 25788                     stack->handler_data);
 25789 }
 25790 
 25791 /* Begin trapping X errors for display DPY.
 25792 
 25793    After calling this function, X protocol errors generated on DPY no
 25794    longer cause Emacs to exit; instead, they are recorded in an error
 25795    handler pushed onto the stack `x_error_message'.
 25796 
 25797    Calling x_check_errors signals an Emacs error if an X error has
 25798    occurred since the last call to x_catch_errors or x_check_errors.
 25799 
 25800    Calling x_uncatch_errors resumes the normal error handling,
 25801    skipping an XSync if the last request made is known to have been
 25802    processed.  Calling x_uncatch_errors_after_check is similar, but
 25803    always skips an XSync to the server, and should be used only
 25804    immediately after x_had_errors_p or x_check_errors, or when it is
 25805    known that no requests have been made since the last x_catch_errors
 25806    call for DPY.
 25807 
 25808    There is no need to use this mechanism for ignoring errors from
 25809    single asynchronous requests, such as sending a ClientMessage to a
 25810    window that might no longer exist.  Use
 25811    x_ignore_errors_for_next_request (paired with
 25812    x_stop_ignoring_errors) instead.  */
 25813 
 25814 void
 25815 x_catch_errors_with_handler (Display *dpy, x_special_error_handler handler,
 25816                              void *handler_data)
 25817 {
 25818   struct x_error_message_stack *data;
 25819 
 25820   data = xzalloc (sizeof *data);
 25821   data->dpy = dpy;
 25822   data->handler = handler;
 25823   data->handler_data = handler_data;
 25824   data->prev = x_error_message;
 25825   data->first_request = XNextRequest (dpy);
 25826   x_error_message = data;
 25827 
 25828   ++x_error_message_count;
 25829 }
 25830 
 25831 void
 25832 x_catch_errors (Display *dpy)
 25833 {
 25834   x_catch_errors_with_handler (dpy, NULL, NULL);
 25835 }
 25836 
 25837 /* Return if errors for REQUEST should be ignored even if there is no
 25838    error handler applied.  */
 25839 static struct x_failable_request *
 25840 x_request_can_fail (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo,
 25841                     unsigned long request)
 25842 {
 25843   struct x_failable_request *failable_requests;
 25844 
 25845   for (failable_requests = dpyinfo->failable_requests;
 25846        failable_requests < dpyinfo->next_failable_request;
 25847        failable_requests++)
 25848     {
 25849       if (x_is_serial_more_than_or_equal_to (request,
 25850                                              failable_requests->start)
 25851           && (!failable_requests->end
 25852               || x_is_serial_less_than_or_equal_to (request,
 25853                                                     failable_requests->end)))
 25854         return failable_requests;
 25855     }
 25856 
 25857   return NULL;
 25858 }
 25859 
 25860 /* Remove outdated request serials from
 25861    dpyinfo->failable_requests.  */
 25862 static void
 25863 x_clean_failable_requests (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo)
 25864 {
 25865   struct x_failable_request *first, *last;
 25866 
 25867   last = dpyinfo->next_failable_request;
 25868 
 25869   for (first = dpyinfo->failable_requests; first < last; first++)
 25870     {
 25871       if (x_is_serial_more_than (first->start,
 25872                                  LastKnownRequestProcessed (dpyinfo->display))
 25873           || !first->end
 25874           || x_is_serial_more_than (first->end,
 25875                                     LastKnownRequestProcessed (dpyinfo->display)))
 25876         break;
 25877     }
 25878 
 25879   if (first != last)
 25880     memmove (&dpyinfo->failable_requests, first,
 25881              sizeof *first * (last - first));
 25882 
 25883   dpyinfo->next_failable_request = (dpyinfo->failable_requests
 25884                                     + (last - first));
 25885 }
 25886 
 25887 /* Protect a section of X requests: ignore errors generated by X
 25888    requests made from now until `x_stop_ignoring_errors'.  Each call
 25889    must be paired with a call to `x_stop_ignoring_errors', and
 25890    recursive calls inside the protected section are not allowed.
 25891 
 25892    The advantage over x_catch_errors followed by
 25893    x_uncatch_errors_after_check is that this function does not sync to
 25894    catch errors if requests were made.  It should be used instead of
 25895    those two functions for catching errors around requests that do not
 25896    require a reply.
 25897 
 25898    As a special feature intended to support xselect.c,
 25899    SELECTION_SERIAL may be an arbitrary number greater than zero: when
 25900    that is the case, x_select_handle_selection_error is called with
 25901    the specified number to delete the selection request that
 25902    encountered the error.  */
 25903 
 25904 void
 25905 x_ignore_errors_for_next_request (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo,
 25906                                   unsigned int selection_serial)
 25907 {
 25908   struct x_failable_request *request, *max;
 25909   unsigned long next_request;
 25910 #ifdef HAVE_GTK3
 25911   GdkDisplay *gdpy;
 25912 #endif
 25913 
 25914   /* This code is not reentrant, so be sure nothing calls it
 25915      recursively in response to input.  */
 25916   block_input ();
 25917 
 25918 #ifdef HAVE_GTK3
 25919   /* GTK 3 tends to override our own error handler inside certain
 25920      callbacks, which this can be called from.  Instead of trying to
 25921      restore our own, add a trap for the following requests with
 25922      GDK as well.  */
 25923 
 25924   gdpy = gdk_x11_lookup_xdisplay (dpyinfo->display);
 25925 
 25926   if (gdpy)
 25927     gdk_x11_display_error_trap_push (gdpy);
 25928 #endif
 25929 
 25930   if ((dpyinfo->next_failable_request
 25931        != dpyinfo->failable_requests)
 25932       && (dpyinfo->next_failable_request - 1)->end == 0)
 25933     /* A new sequence should never be started before an old one
 25934        finishes.  Use `x_catch_errors' to nest error handlers.  */
 25935     emacs_abort ();
 25936 
 25937   request = dpyinfo->next_failable_request;
 25938   max = dpyinfo->failable_requests + N_FAILABLE_REQUESTS;
 25939   next_request = XNextRequest (dpyinfo->display);
 25940 
 25941   if (request >= max)
 25942     {
 25943       /* There is no point in making this extra sync if all requests
 25944          are known to have been fully processed.  */
 25945       if ((LastKnownRequestProcessed (dpyinfo->display)
 25946            != next_request - 1))
 25947         XSync (dpyinfo->display, False);
 25948 
 25949       x_clean_failable_requests (dpyinfo);
 25950       request = dpyinfo->next_failable_request;
 25951     }
 25952 
 25953   if (request >= max)
 25954     /* A request should always be made immediately after calling this
 25955        function.  */
 25956     emacs_abort ();
 25957 
 25958   request->start = next_request;
 25959   request->end = 0;
 25960   request->selection_serial = selection_serial;
 25961 
 25962   dpyinfo->next_failable_request++;
 25963 }
 25964 
 25965 void
 25966 x_stop_ignoring_errors (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo)
 25967 {
 25968   struct x_failable_request *range;
 25969 #ifdef HAVE_GTK3
 25970   GdkDisplay *gdpy;
 25971 #endif
 25972 
 25973   range = dpyinfo->next_failable_request - 1;
 25974   range->end = XNextRequest (dpyinfo->display) - 1;
 25975 
 25976   /* Abort if no request was made since
 25977      `x_ignore_errors_for_next_request'.  */
 25978 
 25979   if (x_is_serial_less_than (range->end, range->start))
 25980     emacs_abort ();
 25981 
 25982 #ifdef HAVE_GTK3
 25983   gdpy = gdk_x11_lookup_xdisplay (dpyinfo->display);
 25984 
 25985   if (gdpy)
 25986     gdk_x11_display_error_trap_pop_ignored (gdpy);
 25987 #endif
 25988 
 25989   unblock_input ();
 25990 }
 25991 
 25992 /* Undo the last x_catch_errors call.
 25993    DPY should be the display that was passed to x_catch_errors.
 25994 
 25995    This version should be used only if the immediately preceding
 25996    X-protocol-related thing was x_check_errors or x_had_error_p, both
 25997    of which issue XSync calls, so we don't need to re-sync here.  */
 25998 
 25999 void
 26000 x_uncatch_errors_after_check (void)
 26001 {
 26002   struct x_error_message_stack *tmp;
 26003 
 26004   block_input ();
 26005   tmp = x_error_message;
 26006   x_error_message = x_error_message->prev;
 26007   --x_error_message_count;
 26008   if (tmp->string)
 26009     xfree (tmp->string);
 26010   xfree (tmp);
 26011   unblock_input ();
 26012 }
 26013 
 26014 /* Undo the last x_catch_errors call.  */
 26015 
 26016 void
 26017 x_uncatch_errors (void)
 26018 {
 26019   struct x_error_message_stack *tmp;
 26020   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo;
 26021 
 26022   /* In rare situations when running Emacs run in daemon mode,
 26023      shutting down an emacsclient via delete-frame can cause
 26024      x_uncatch_errors to be called when x_error_message is set to
 26025      NULL.  */
 26026   if (x_error_message == NULL)
 26027     return;
 26028 
 26029   block_input ();
 26030 
 26031   dpyinfo = x_display_info_for_display (x_error_message->dpy);
 26032 
 26033   /* The display may have been closed before this function is called.
 26034      Check if it is still open before calling XSync.  */
 26035   if (dpyinfo != 0
 26036       /* There is no point in making this extra sync if all requests
 26037          are known to have been fully processed.  */
 26038       && (LastKnownRequestProcessed (x_error_message->dpy)
 26039           != XNextRequest (x_error_message->dpy) - 1)
 26040       /* Likewise if no request was made since the trap was
 26041          installed.  */
 26042       && (NextRequest (x_error_message->dpy)
 26043           > x_error_message->first_request))
 26044     {
 26045       XSync (x_error_message->dpy, False);
 26046       x_clean_failable_requests (dpyinfo);
 26047     }
 26048 
 26049   tmp = x_error_message;
 26050   x_error_message = x_error_message->prev;
 26051   --x_error_message_count;
 26052   if (tmp->string)
 26053     xfree (tmp->string);
 26054   xfree (tmp);
 26055   unblock_input ();
 26056 }
 26057 
 26058 /* If any X protocol errors have arrived since the last call to
 26059    x_catch_errors or x_check_errors, signal an Emacs error using
 26060    sprintf (a buffer, FORMAT, the x error message text) as the text.  */
 26061 
 26062 void
 26063 x_check_errors (Display *dpy, const char *format)
 26064 {
 26065   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo;
 26066   char *string;
 26067 
 26068   /* This shouldn't happen, since x_check_errors should be called
 26069      immediately inside an x_catch_errors block.  */
 26070   if (dpy != x_error_message->dpy)
 26071     emacs_abort ();
 26072 
 26073   /* There is no point in making this extra sync if all requests
 26074      are known to have been fully processed.  */
 26075   if ((LastKnownRequestProcessed (dpy)
 26076        != XNextRequest (dpy) - 1)
 26077       && (NextRequest (dpy)
 26078           > x_error_message->first_request))
 26079     XSync (dpy, False);
 26080 
 26081   dpyinfo = x_display_info_for_display (dpy);
 26082 
 26083   /* Clean the array of failable requests, since a sync happened.  */
 26084   if (dpyinfo)
 26085     x_clean_failable_requests (dpyinfo);
 26086 
 26087   if (x_error_message->string)
 26088     {
 26089       string = alloca (strlen (x_error_message->string) + 1);
 26090       strcpy (string, x_error_message->string);
 26091 
 26092       error (format, string);
 26093     }
 26094 }
 26095 
 26096 /* Nonzero if any X protocol errors were generated since the last call
 26097    to x_catch_errors on DPY.  */
 26098 
 26099 bool
 26100 x_had_errors_p (Display *dpy)
 26101 {
 26102   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo;
 26103 
 26104   /* This shouldn't happen, since x_check_errors should be called
 26105      immediately inside an x_catch_errors block.  */
 26106   if (dpy != x_error_message->dpy)
 26107     emacs_abort ();
 26108 
 26109   /* Make sure to catch any errors incurred so far.  */
 26110   if ((LastKnownRequestProcessed (dpy)
 26111        != XNextRequest (dpy) - 1)
 26112       && (NextRequest (dpy)
 26113           > x_error_message->first_request))
 26114     XSync (dpy, False);
 26115 
 26116   dpyinfo = x_display_info_for_display (dpy);
 26117 
 26118   /* Clean the array of failable requests, since a sync happened.  */
 26119   if (dpyinfo)
 26120     x_clean_failable_requests (dpyinfo);
 26121 
 26122   return !!x_error_message->string;
 26123 }
 26124 
 26125 /* Forget about any errors we have had, since we did x_catch_errors on
 26126    DPY.  */
 26127 
 26128 void
 26129 x_clear_errors (Display *dpy)
 26130 {
 26131   /* This shouldn't happen, since x_check_errors should be called
 26132      immediately inside an x_catch_errors block.  */
 26133   if (dpy != x_error_message->dpy)
 26134     emacs_abort ();
 26135 
 26136   xfree (x_error_message->string);
 26137   x_error_message->string = NULL;
 26138 }
 26139 
 26140 #if false
 26141       /* See comment in unwind_to_catch why calling this is a bad
 26142        * idea.  --lorentey   */
 26143 /* Close off all unclosed x_catch_errors calls.  */
 26144 
 26145 void
 26146 x_fully_uncatch_errors (void)
 26147 {
 26148   while (x_error_message)
 26149     x_uncatch_errors ();
 26150 }
 26151 #endif
 26152 
 26153 #if false
 26154 static unsigned int x_wire_count;
 26155 
 26156 static int
 26157 x_trace_wire (Display *dpy)
 26158 {
 26159   fprintf (stderr, "Lib call: %u\n", ++x_wire_count);
 26160   return 0;
 26161 }
 26162 #endif
 26163 
 26164 
 26165 /************************************************************************
 26166                           Handling X errors
 26167  ************************************************************************/
 26168 
 26169 /* Error message passed to x_connection_closed.  */
 26170 
 26171 static char *error_msg;
 26172 
 26173 /* Try to find a frame in Vframe_list, and make it the selected frame.
 26174    `delete_frame' sometimes misses the initial frame for an unknown
 26175    reason when Emacs is running as a background daemon.  */
 26176 
 26177 static void
 26178 x_try_restore_frame (void)
 26179 {
 26180   Lisp_Object tail, frame;
 26181 
 26182   FOR_EACH_FRAME (tail, frame)
 26183     {
 26184       if (!NILP (do_switch_frame (frame, 0, 1, Qnil)))
 26185         return;
 26186     }
 26187 }
 26188 
 26189 /* Handle the loss of connection to display DPY.  ERROR_MESSAGE is
 26190    the text of an error message that lead to the connection loss.  */
 26191 
 26192 static void
 26193 x_connection_closed (Display *dpy, const char *error_message, bool ioerror)
 26194 {
 26195   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo;
 26196   Lisp_Object frame, tail;
 26197   specpdl_ref idx = SPECPDL_INDEX ();
 26198   Emacs_XIOErrorHandler io_error_handler;
 26199   xm_drop_start_message dmsg;
 26200   struct frame *f;
 26201   Lisp_Object minibuf_frame, tmp;
 26202   struct x_failable_request *failable;
 26203   struct x_error_message_stack *stack;
 26204   static Display *current_display;
 26205 
 26206   /* Prevent recursive calls of this function for the same display.
 26207      This is because destroying a frame might still cause an IO error
 26208      in some cases.  (bug#56528) */
 26209   if (current_display == dpy)
 26210     return;
 26211 
 26212   current_display = dpy;
 26213 
 26214   dpyinfo = x_display_info_for_display (dpy);
 26215   error_msg = alloca (strlen (error_message) + 1);
 26216   strcpy (error_msg, error_message);
 26217 
 26218   /* Inhibit redisplay while frames are being deleted. */
 26219   specbind (Qinhibit_redisplay, Qt);
 26220 
 26221   /* If drag-and-drop is in progress, cancel drag-and-drop.  If DND
 26222      frame's display is DPY, don't reset event masks or try to send
 26223      responses to other programs because the display is going
 26224      away.  */
 26225 
 26226   if (x_dnd_in_progress || x_dnd_waiting_for_finish)
 26227     {
 26228       if (!ioerror)
 26229         {
 26230           /* Handle display disconnect errors here because this function
 26231              is not reentrant at this particular spot.  */
 26232           io_error_handler = XSetIOErrorHandler (x_dnd_io_error_handler);
 26233 
 26234           if (!!sigsetjmp (x_dnd_disconnect_handler, 1)
 26235               && x_dnd_in_progress
 26236               && dpy == (x_dnd_waiting_for_finish
 26237                          ? x_dnd_finish_display
 26238                          : FRAME_X_DISPLAY (x_dnd_frame)))
 26239             {
 26240               /* Clean up drag and drop if the drag frame's display isn't
 26241                  the one being disconnected.  */
 26242               f = x_dnd_frame;
 26243 
 26244               if (x_dnd_last_seen_window != None
 26245                   && x_dnd_last_protocol_version != -1)
 26246                 x_dnd_send_leave (x_dnd_frame,
 26247                                   x_dnd_last_seen_window,
 26248                                   x_dnd_last_seen_toplevel);
 26249               else if (x_dnd_last_seen_window != None
 26250                        && !XM_DRAG_STYLE_IS_DROP_ONLY (x_dnd_last_motif_style)
 26251                        && x_dnd_last_motif_style != XM_DRAG_STYLE_NONE
 26252                        && x_dnd_motif_setup_p)
 26253                 {
 26254                   dmsg.reason = XM_DRAG_REASON (XM_DRAG_ORIGINATOR_INITIATOR,
 26255                                                 XM_DRAG_REASON_DROP_START);
 26256                   dmsg.byte_order = XM_BYTE_ORDER_CUR_FIRST;
 26257                   dmsg.timestamp = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f)->last_user_time;
 26258                   dmsg.side_effects
 26259                     = XM_DRAG_SIDE_EFFECT (xm_side_effect_from_action (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f),
 26260                                                                        x_dnd_wanted_action),
 26261                                            XM_DROP_SITE_VALID, x_dnd_motif_operations,
 26262                                            XM_DROP_ACTION_DROP_CANCEL);
 26263                   dmsg.x = 0;
 26264                   dmsg.y = 0;
 26265                   dmsg.index_atom = x_dnd_motif_atom;
 26266                   dmsg.source_window = FRAME_X_WINDOW (f);
 26267 
 26268                   x_dnd_send_xm_leave_for_drop (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f), f,
 26269                                                 x_dnd_last_seen_window, 0);
 26270                   xm_send_drop_message (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f), FRAME_X_WINDOW (f),
 26271                                         x_dnd_last_seen_window, &dmsg);
 26272                 }
 26273             }
 26274 
 26275           XSetIOErrorHandler (io_error_handler);
 26276         }
 26277 
 26278       dpyinfo = x_display_info_for_display (dpy);
 26279 
 26280       x_dnd_last_seen_window = None;
 26281       x_dnd_last_seen_toplevel = None;
 26282       x_dnd_in_progress = false;
 26283       x_dnd_waiting_for_finish = false;
 26284 
 26285       if (x_dnd_use_toplevels)
 26286         x_dnd_free_toplevels (!ioerror);
 26287 
 26288       x_dnd_return_frame_object = NULL;
 26289       x_dnd_movement_frame = NULL;
 26290       x_dnd_wheel_frame = NULL;
 26291       x_dnd_frame = NULL;
 26292     }
 26293 
 26294   if (dpyinfo)
 26295     {
 26296       /* Protect display from being closed when we delete the last
 26297          frame on it. */
 26298       dpyinfo->reference_count++;
 26299       dpyinfo->terminal->reference_count++;
 26300       if (ioerror)
 26301         dpyinfo->display = 0;
 26302     }
 26303 
 26304   /* delete_frame can still try to read async input (even though we
 26305      tell pass `noelisp'), because looking up the `delete-before'
 26306      parameter calls Fassq which then calls maybe_quit.  So block
 26307      input while deleting frames.  */
 26308   block_input ();
 26309 
 26310   /* First delete frames whose mini-buffers are on frames
 26311      that are on the dead display.  */
 26312   FOR_EACH_FRAME (tail, frame)
 26313     {
 26314       /* Tooltip frames don't have these, so avoid crashing.  */
 26315 
 26316       if (FRAME_TOOLTIP_P (XFRAME (frame)))
 26317         continue;
 26318 
 26319       minibuf_frame
 26320         = WINDOW_FRAME (XWINDOW (FRAME_MINIBUF_WINDOW (XFRAME (frame))));
 26321 
 26322       if (FRAME_X_P (XFRAME (frame))
 26323           && FRAME_X_P (XFRAME (minibuf_frame))
 26324           && ! EQ (frame, minibuf_frame)
 26325           && FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (XFRAME (minibuf_frame)) == dpyinfo)
 26326         delete_frame (frame, Qnoelisp);
 26327     }
 26328 
 26329   /* Now delete all remaining frames on the dead display.
 26330      We are now sure none of these is used as the mini-buffer
 26331      for another frame that we need to delete.  */
 26332   FOR_EACH_FRAME (tail, frame)
 26333     if (FRAME_X_P (XFRAME (frame))
 26334         && FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (XFRAME (frame)) == dpyinfo)
 26335       {
 26336         /* Set this to t so that delete_frame won't get confused
 26337            trying to find a replacement.  */
 26338         kset_default_minibuffer_frame (FRAME_KBOARD (XFRAME (frame)), Qt);
 26339         delete_frame (frame, Qnoelisp);
 26340       }
 26341 
 26342   /* If DPYINFO is null, this means we didn't open the display in the
 26343      first place, so don't try to close it.  */
 26344   if (dpyinfo)
 26345     {
 26346       /* We can not call XtCloseDisplay here because it calls XSync.
 26347          XSync inside the error handler apparently hangs Emacs.  On
 26348          current Xt versions, this isn't needed either.  */
 26349 #ifdef USE_GTK
 26350       /* A long-standing GTK bug prevents proper disconnect handling
 26351          <https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/issues/221>.  Once,
 26352          the resulting Glib error message loop filled a user's disk.
 26353          To avoid this, kill Emacs unconditionally on disconnect.  */
 26354       shut_down_emacs (0, Qnil);
 26355       fprintf (stderr, "%s\n\
 26356 When compiled with GTK, Emacs cannot recover from X disconnects.\n\
 26357 This is a GTK bug: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/issues/221\n\
 26358 For details, see etc/PROBLEMS.\n",
 26359                error_msg);
 26360       emacs_abort ();
 26361 #endif /* USE_GTK */
 26362 
 26363       /* Indicate that this display is dead.  */
 26364       dpyinfo->display = 0;
 26365 
 26366       dpyinfo->reference_count--;
 26367       dpyinfo->terminal->reference_count--;
 26368       if (dpyinfo->reference_count != 0)
 26369         /* We have just closed all frames on this display. */
 26370         emacs_abort ();
 26371 
 26372       /* This was the last terminal remaining, so print the error
 26373          message and associated error handlers and kill Emacs.  */
 26374       if (dpyinfo->terminal == terminal_list
 26375           && !terminal_list->next_terminal)
 26376         {
 26377           fprintf (stderr, "%s\n", error_msg);
 26378 
 26379           if (!ioerror && dpyinfo)
 26380             {
 26381               /* Dump the list of error handlers for debugging
 26382                  purposes if the list exists.  */
 26383 
 26384               if ((dpyinfo->failable_requests
 26385                    != dpyinfo->next_failable_request) || x_error_message)
 26386                 fprintf (stderr, "X error handlers currently installed:\n");
 26387 
 26388               for (failable = dpyinfo->failable_requests;
 26389                    failable < dpyinfo->next_failable_request;
 26390                    ++failable)
 26391                 {
 26392                   if (failable->end)
 26393                     fprintf (stderr, "Ignoring errors between %lu to %lu\n",
 26394                              failable->start, failable->end);
 26395                   else
 26396                     fprintf (stderr, "Ignoring errors from %lu onwards\n",
 26397                              failable->start);
 26398                 }
 26399 
 26400               for (stack = x_error_message; stack; stack = stack->prev)
 26401                 fprintf (stderr, "Trapping errors from %lu\n",
 26402                          stack->first_request);
 26403             }
 26404         }
 26405 
 26406       XSETTERMINAL (tmp, dpyinfo->terminal);
 26407       Fdelete_terminal (tmp, Qnoelisp);
 26408     }
 26409 
 26410   /* The initial "daemon" frame is sometimes not selected by
 26411      `delete_frame' when Emacs is a background daemon.  */
 26412   if (NILP (selected_frame))
 26413     x_try_restore_frame ();
 26414 
 26415   unblock_input ();
 26416 
 26417   /* Sometimes another terminal is still alive, but deleting this
 26418      terminal caused all frames to vanish.  In that case, simply kill
 26419      Emacs, since the next redisplay will abort as there is no more
 26420      selected frame.  (bug#56528) */
 26421   if (terminal_list == 0 || NILP (selected_frame))
 26422     Fkill_emacs (make_fixnum (70), Qnil);
 26423 
 26424   totally_unblock_input ();
 26425 
 26426   unbind_to (idx, Qnil);
 26427   clear_waiting_for_input ();
 26428 
 26429   /* Here, we absolutely have to use a non-local exit (e.g. signal, throw,
 26430      longjmp), because returning from this function would get us back into
 26431      Xlib's code which will directly call `exit'.  */
 26432   current_display = NULL;
 26433   error ("%s", error_msg);
 26434 }
 26435 
 26436 static void x_error_quitter (Display *, XErrorEvent *);
 26437 
 26438 /* This is the first-level handler for X protocol errors.
 26439    It calls x_error_quitter or x_error_catcher.  */
 26440 
 26441 static int
 26442 x_error_handler (Display *display, XErrorEvent *event)
 26443 {
 26444   struct x_error_message_stack *stack;
 26445   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo;
 26446   struct x_failable_request *fail, *last;
 26447 
 26448 #if defined USE_GTK && defined HAVE_GTK3
 26449   if ((event->error_code == BadMatch
 26450        || event->error_code == BadWindow)
 26451       && event->request_code == X_SetInputFocus)
 26452     return 0;
 26453 #endif
 26454 
 26455   dpyinfo = x_display_info_for_display (display);
 26456 
 26457   if (dpyinfo)
 26458     {
 26459       fail = x_request_can_fail (dpyinfo, event->serial);
 26460 
 26461       if (fail)
 26462         {
 26463           /* Now that this request sequence has been fully handled,
 26464              remove it from the list of requests that can fail.  */
 26465 
 26466           if (event->serial == fail->end)
 26467             {
 26468               last = dpyinfo->next_failable_request;
 26469               memmove (&dpyinfo->failable_requests, fail,
 26470                        sizeof *fail * (last - fail));
 26471               dpyinfo->next_failable_request = (dpyinfo->failable_requests
 26472                                                 + (last - fail));
 26473             }
 26474 
 26475           /* If a selection transfer is the cause of this error,
 26476              remove the selection transfer now.  */
 26477           if (fail->selection_serial)
 26478             x_handle_selection_error (fail->selection_serial,
 26479                                       event);
 26480 
 26481           return 0;
 26482         }
 26483     }
 26484 
 26485   /* If we try to ungrab or grab a device that doesn't exist anymore
 26486      (that happens a lot in xmenu.c), just ignore the error.  */
 26487 
 26488 #ifdef HAVE_XINPUT2
 26489   /* Handle errors from some specific XI2 requests here to avoid a
 26490      sync in handle_one_xevent.  */
 26491   if (dpyinfo && dpyinfo->supports_xi2
 26492       && event->request_code == dpyinfo->xi2_opcode
 26493       && (event->minor_code == X_XIGrabDevice
 26494           || event->minor_code == X_XIUngrabDevice
 26495           || event->minor_code == X_XIAllowEvents))
 26496     return 0;
 26497 #endif
 26498 
 26499   stack = x_find_error_handler (display, event);
 26500 
 26501   if (stack)
 26502     x_error_catcher (display, event, stack);
 26503   else
 26504     x_error_quitter (display, event);
 26505   return 0;
 26506 }
 26507 
 26508 /* This is the usual handler for X protocol errors.
 26509    It kills all frames on the display that we got the error for.
 26510    If that was the only one, it prints an error message and kills Emacs.  */
 26511 
 26512 /* .gdbinit puts a breakpoint here, so make sure it is not inlined.  */
 26513 
 26514 static void NO_INLINE
 26515 x_error_quitter (Display *display, XErrorEvent *event)
 26516 {
 26517   char buf[256], buf1[800 + INT_STRLEN_BOUND (int)
 26518                       + INT_STRLEN_BOUND (unsigned long)
 26519                       + INT_STRLEN_BOUND (XID)
 26520                       + INT_STRLEN_BOUND (int)];
 26521 
 26522   /* Ignore BadName errors.  They can happen because of fonts
 26523      or colors that are not defined.  */
 26524 
 26525   if (event->error_code == BadName)
 26526     return;
 26527 
 26528   /* Note that there is no real way portable across R3/R4 to get the
 26529      original error handler.  */
 26530 
 26531   XGetErrorText (display, event->error_code, buf, sizeof (buf));
 26532   sprintf (buf1, "X protocol error: %s on protocol request %d\n"
 26533            "Serial no: %lu\n"
 26534            "Failing resource ID (if any): 0x%lx\n"
 26535            "Minor code: %d\n"
 26536            "This is a bug!  Please report this to bug-gnu-emacs@gnu.org!\n",
 26537            buf, event->request_code, event->serial, event->resourceid,
 26538            event->minor_code);
 26539   x_connection_closed (display, buf1, false);
 26540 }
 26541 
 26542 
 26543 /* This is the handler for X IO errors, always.
 26544    It kills all frames on the display that we lost touch with.
 26545    If that was the only one, it prints an error message and kills Emacs.  */
 26546 
 26547 static int NO_INLINE
 26548 x_io_error_quitter (Display *display)
 26549 {
 26550   char buf[256];
 26551 
 26552   snprintf (buf, sizeof buf, "Connection lost to X server '%s'",
 26553             DisplayString (display));
 26554   x_connection_closed (display, buf, true);
 26555 
 26556   return 0;
 26557 }
 26558 
 26559 
 26560 /* Changing the font of the frame.  */
 26561 
 26562 /* Give frame F the font FONT-OBJECT as its default font.  The return
 26563    value is FONT-OBJECT.  FONTSET is an ID of the fontset for the
 26564    frame.  If it is negative, generate a new fontset from
 26565    FONT-OBJECT.  */
 26566 
 26567 static Lisp_Object
 26568 x_new_font (struct frame *f, Lisp_Object font_object, int fontset)
 26569 {
 26570   struct font *font = XFONT_OBJECT (font_object);
 26571   int unit, font_ascent, font_descent;
 26572 
 26573   if (fontset < 0)
 26574     fontset = fontset_from_font (font_object);
 26575   FRAME_FONTSET (f) = fontset;
 26576   if (FRAME_FONT (f) == font)
 26577     /* This font is already set in frame F.  There's nothing more to
 26578        do.  */
 26579     return font_object;
 26580 
 26581   FRAME_FONT (f) = font;
 26582   FRAME_BASELINE_OFFSET (f) = font->baseline_offset;
 26583   FRAME_COLUMN_WIDTH (f) = font->average_width;
 26584   get_font_ascent_descent (font, &font_ascent, &font_descent);
 26585   FRAME_LINE_HEIGHT (f) = font_ascent + font_descent;
 26586 
 26587 #ifndef USE_X_TOOLKIT
 26588   FRAME_MENU_BAR_HEIGHT (f) = FRAME_MENU_BAR_LINES (f) * FRAME_LINE_HEIGHT (f);
 26589 #endif
 26590   /* We could use a more elaborate calculation here.  */
 26591   FRAME_TAB_BAR_HEIGHT (f) = FRAME_TAB_BAR_LINES (f) * FRAME_LINE_HEIGHT (f);
 26592 
 26593   /* Compute character columns occupied by scrollbar.
 26594 
 26595      Don't do things differently for non-toolkit scrollbars
 26596      (Bug#17163).  */
 26597   unit = FRAME_COLUMN_WIDTH (f);
 26598   if (FRAME_CONFIG_SCROLL_BAR_WIDTH (f) > 0)
 26599     FRAME_CONFIG_SCROLL_BAR_COLS (f)
 26600       = (FRAME_CONFIG_SCROLL_BAR_WIDTH (f) + unit - 1) / unit;
 26601   else
 26602     FRAME_CONFIG_SCROLL_BAR_COLS (f) = (14 + unit - 1) / unit;
 26603 
 26604 
 26605   /* Don't change the size of a tip frame; there's no point in doing it
 26606      because it's done in Fx_show_tip, and it leads to problems because
 26607      the tip frame has no widget.  */
 26608   if (FRAME_X_WINDOW (f) != 0 && !FRAME_TOOLTIP_P (f))
 26609     adjust_frame_size
 26610       (f, FRAME_COLS (f) * FRAME_COLUMN_WIDTH (f),
 26611        FRAME_LINES (f) * FRAME_LINE_HEIGHT (f), 3, false, Qfont);
 26612 
 26613 #ifdef HAVE_X_I18N
 26614   if (FRAME_XIC (f)
 26615       && (FRAME_XIC_STYLE (f) & (XIMPreeditPosition | XIMStatusArea)))
 26616     {
 26617       block_input ();
 26618       xic_set_xfontset (f, SSDATA (fontset_ascii (fontset)));
 26619       unblock_input ();
 26620     }
 26621 #endif
 26622 
 26623   return font_object;
 26624 }
 26625 
 26626 
 26627 /***********************************************************************
 26628                            X Input Methods
 26629  ***********************************************************************/
 26630 
 26631 #ifdef HAVE_X_I18N
 26632 
 26633 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6
 26634 
 26635 /* HAVE_X11R6 means Xlib conforms to the R6 specification or later.
 26636    HAVE_X11R6_XIM, OTOH, means that Emacs should try to use R6-style
 26637    callback driven input method initialization.  They are separate
 26638    because Sun apparently ships buggy Xlib with some versions of
 26639    Solaris... */
 26640 
 26641 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6_XIM
 26642 
 26643 /* If preedit text is set on F, cancel preedit, free the text, and
 26644    generate the appropriate events to cancel the preedit display.
 26645 
 26646    This is mainly useful when the connection to the IM server is
 26647    dropped during preconversion.  */
 26648 
 26649 static void
 26650 x_maybe_clear_preedit (struct frame *f)
 26651 {
 26652   struct x_output *output;
 26653   struct input_event ie;
 26654 
 26655   output = FRAME_X_OUTPUT (f);
 26656 
 26657   if (!output->preedit_chars)
 26658     return;
 26659 
 26660   EVENT_INIT (ie);
 26661   ie.kind = PREEDIT_TEXT_EVENT;
 26662   ie.arg = Qnil;
 26663   XSETFRAME (ie.frame_or_window, f);
 26664   XSETINT (ie.x, 0);
 26665   XSETINT (ie.y, 0);
 26666   kbd_buffer_store_event (&ie);
 26667 
 26668   xfree (output->preedit_chars);
 26669 
 26670   output->preedit_size = 0;
 26671   output->preedit_active = false;
 26672   output->preedit_chars = NULL;
 26673   output->preedit_caret = 0;
 26674 }
 26675 
 26676 /* XIM destroy callback function, which is called whenever the
 26677    connection to input method XIM dies.  CLIENT_DATA contains a
 26678    pointer to the x_display_info structure corresponding to XIM.  */
 26679 
 26680 static void
 26681 xim_destroy_callback (XIM xim, XPointer client_data, XPointer call_data)
 26682 {
 26683   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = (struct x_display_info *) client_data;
 26684   Lisp_Object frame, tail;
 26685 
 26686   block_input ();
 26687 
 26688   /* No need to call XDestroyIC.. */
 26689   FOR_EACH_FRAME (tail, frame)
 26690     {
 26691       struct frame *f = XFRAME (frame);
 26692       if (FRAME_X_P (f) && FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f) == dpyinfo)
 26693         {
 26694           FRAME_XIC (f) = NULL;
 26695           xic_free_xfontset (f);
 26696 
 26697           /* Free the preedit text if necessary.  */
 26698           x_maybe_clear_preedit (f);
 26699         }
 26700     }
 26701 
 26702   /* No need to call XCloseIM.  */
 26703   dpyinfo->xim = NULL;
 26704 
 26705   /* Also free IM values; those are allocated separately upon
 26706      XGetIMValues.  */
 26707   if (dpyinfo->xim_styles)
 26708     XFree (dpyinfo->xim_styles);
 26709   dpyinfo->xim_styles = NULL;
 26710   unblock_input ();
 26711 }
 26712 
 26713 #endif
 26714 
 26715 #endif /* HAVE_X11R6 */
 26716 
 26717 /* Open the connection to the XIM server on display DPYINFO.
 26718    RESOURCE_NAME is the resource name Emacs uses.  */
 26719 
 26720 static void
 26721 xim_open_dpy (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo, char *resource_name)
 26722 {
 26723 #ifdef HAVE_XIM
 26724   XIM xim;
 26725   const char *locale;
 26726 
 26727   if (dpyinfo->use_xim)
 26728     {
 26729       if (dpyinfo->xim)
 26730         {
 26731           XCloseIM (dpyinfo->xim);
 26732 
 26733           /* Free values left over from the last time the IM
 26734              connection was established.  */
 26735 
 26736           if (dpyinfo->xim_styles)
 26737             XFree (dpyinfo->xim_styles);
 26738           dpyinfo->xim_styles = NULL;
 26739         }
 26740 
 26741       xim = XOpenIM (dpyinfo->display, dpyinfo->rdb, resource_name,
 26742                      emacs_class);
 26743       dpyinfo->xim = xim;
 26744 
 26745       if (xim)
 26746         {
 26747 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6_XIM
 26748           XIMCallback destroy;
 26749 #endif
 26750 
 26751           /* Get supported styles and XIM values.  */
 26752           XGetIMValues (xim, XNQueryInputStyle, &dpyinfo->xim_styles, NULL);
 26753 
 26754 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6_XIM
 26755           destroy.callback = xim_destroy_callback;
 26756           destroy.client_data = (XPointer)dpyinfo;
 26757           XSetIMValues (xim, XNDestroyCallback, &destroy, NULL);
 26758 #endif
 26759 
 26760           locale = XLocaleOfIM (xim);
 26761 
 26762           /* Now try to determine the coding system that should be
 26763              used.  locale is in Host Portable Character Encoding, and
 26764              as such can be passed to build_string as is.  */
 26765           dpyinfo->xim_coding = safe_call1 (Vx_input_coding_function,
 26766                                             build_string (locale));
 26767         }
 26768     }
 26769   else
 26770 #endif /* HAVE_XIM */
 26771     dpyinfo->xim = NULL;
 26772 }
 26773 
 26774 
 26775 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6_XIM
 26776 
 26777 /* XIM instantiate callback function, which is called whenever an XIM
 26778    server is available.  DISPLAY is the display of the XIM.
 26779    CLIENT_DATA contains a pointer to an xim_inst_t structure created
 26780    when the callback was registered.  */
 26781 
 26782 static void
 26783 xim_instantiate_callback (Display *display, XPointer client_data, XPointer call_data)
 26784 {
 26785   struct xim_inst_t *xim_inst = (struct xim_inst_t *) client_data;
 26786   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = xim_inst->dpyinfo;
 26787 
 26788   if (x_dnd_in_progress)
 26789     return;
 26790 
 26791   /* We don't support multiple XIM connections. */
 26792   if (dpyinfo->xim)
 26793     return;
 26794 
 26795   xim_open_dpy (dpyinfo, xim_inst->resource_name);
 26796 
 26797   /* Create XIC for the existing frames on the same display, as long
 26798      as they have no XIC.  */
 26799   if (dpyinfo->xim && dpyinfo->reference_count > 0)
 26800     {
 26801       Lisp_Object tail, frame;
 26802 
 26803       block_input ();
 26804       FOR_EACH_FRAME (tail, frame)
 26805         {
 26806           struct frame *f = XFRAME (frame);
 26807 
 26808           if (FRAME_X_P (f)
 26809               && FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f) == xim_inst->dpyinfo)
 26810             if (FRAME_XIC (f) == NULL)
 26811               {
 26812                 create_frame_xic (f);
 26813                 if (FRAME_XIC_STYLE (f) & XIMStatusArea)
 26814                   xic_set_statusarea (f);
 26815                 struct window *w = XWINDOW (f->selected_window);
 26816                 xic_set_preeditarea (w, w->cursor.x, w->cursor.y);
 26817               }
 26818         }
 26819 
 26820       unblock_input ();
 26821     }
 26822 }
 26823 
 26824 #endif /* HAVE_X11R6_XIM */
 26825 
 26826 
 26827 /* Open a connection to the XIM server on display DPYINFO.
 26828    RESOURCE_NAME is the resource name for Emacs.  On X11R5, open the
 26829    connection only at the first time.  On X11R6, open the connection
 26830    in the XIM instantiate callback function.  */
 26831 
 26832 static void
 26833 xim_initialize (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo, char *resource_name)
 26834 {
 26835   dpyinfo->xim = NULL;
 26836 #ifdef HAVE_XIM
 26837   if (dpyinfo->use_xim)
 26838     {
 26839 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6_XIM
 26840       struct xim_inst_t *xim_inst = xmalloc (sizeof *xim_inst);
 26841       Bool ret;
 26842 
 26843       dpyinfo->xim_callback_data = xim_inst;
 26844       xim_inst->dpyinfo = dpyinfo;
 26845       xim_inst->resource_name = xstrdup (resource_name);
 26846 
 26847       /* The last argument is XPointer in XFree86 but (XPointer *) on
 26848          Tru64, at least, but the configure test doesn't work because
 26849          xim_instantiate_callback can either be XIMProc or XIDProc, so
 26850          just cast to void *.  */
 26851 
 26852       ret = XRegisterIMInstantiateCallback (dpyinfo->display,
 26853                                             dpyinfo->rdb,
 26854                                             xim_inst->resource_name,
 26855                                             emacs_class,
 26856                                             xim_instantiate_callback,
 26857                                             (void *) xim_inst);
 26858       eassert (ret);
 26859 #else /* not HAVE_X11R6_XIM */
 26860       xim_open_dpy (dpyinfo, resource_name);
 26861 #endif /* not HAVE_X11R6_XIM */
 26862     }
 26863 #endif /* HAVE_XIM */
 26864 }
 26865 
 26866 
 26867 /* Close the connection to the XIM server on display DPYINFO.
 26868    Unregister any IM instantiation callback previously installed,
 26869    close the connection to the IM server if possible, and free any
 26870    retrieved IM values.  */
 26871 
 26872 static void
 26873 xim_close_dpy (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo)
 26874 {
 26875 #ifdef HAVE_XIM
 26876 #ifdef HAVE_X11R6_XIM
 26877   struct xim_inst_t *xim_inst;
 26878   Bool rc;
 26879 
 26880   /* If dpyinfo->xim_callback_data is not set, then IM support wasn't
 26881      initialized, which can happen if Xlib doesn't understand the C
 26882      locale being used.  */
 26883 
 26884   if (dpyinfo->xim_callback_data)
 26885     {
 26886       xim_inst = dpyinfo->xim_callback_data;
 26887 
 26888       if (dpyinfo->display)
 26889         {
 26890           rc = XUnregisterIMInstantiateCallback (dpyinfo->display,
 26891                                                  dpyinfo->rdb,
 26892                                                  xim_inst->resource_name,
 26893                                                  emacs_class,
 26894                                                  xim_instantiate_callback,
 26895                                                  (void *) xim_inst);
 26896           eassert (rc);
 26897         }
 26898 
 26899       xfree (xim_inst->resource_name);
 26900       xfree (xim_inst);
 26901     }
 26902 #endif /* HAVE_X11R6_XIM */
 26903 
 26904   /* Now close the connection to the input method server.  This may
 26905      access the display connection, and isn't safe if the display has
 26906      already been closed.  */
 26907 
 26908   if (dpyinfo->display && dpyinfo->xim)
 26909     XCloseIM (dpyinfo->xim);
 26910   dpyinfo->xim = NULL;
 26911 
 26912   /* Free the list of XIM styles retrieved.  */
 26913 
 26914   if (dpyinfo->xim_styles)
 26915     XFree (dpyinfo->xim_styles);
 26916   dpyinfo->xim_styles = NULL;
 26917 #endif /* HAVE_XIM */
 26918 }
 26919 
 26920 #endif /* not HAVE_X11R6_XIM */
 26921 
 26922 
 26923 
 26924 /* Calculate the absolute position in frame F
 26925    from its current recorded position values and gravity.  */
 26926 
 26927 static void
 26928 x_calc_absolute_position (struct frame *f)
 26929 {
 26930   int flags = f->size_hint_flags;
 26931   struct frame *p = FRAME_PARENT_FRAME (f);
 26932 
 26933   /* We have nothing to do if the current position
 26934      is already for the top-left corner.  */
 26935   if (! ((flags & XNegative) || (flags & YNegative)))
 26936     return;
 26937 
 26938   /* Treat negative positions as relative to the leftmost bottommost
 26939      position that fits on the screen.  */
 26940   if ((flags & XNegative) && (f->left_pos <= 0))
 26941     {
 26942       int width = FRAME_PIXEL_WIDTH (f);
 26943 
 26944       /* A frame that has been visible at least once should have outer
 26945          edges.  */
 26946       if (f->output_data.x->has_been_visible && !p)
 26947         {
 26948           Lisp_Object frame;
 26949           Lisp_Object edges = Qnil;
 26950 
 26951           XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 26952           edges = Fx_frame_edges (frame, Qouter_edges);
 26953           if (!NILP (edges))
 26954             width = (XFIXNUM (Fnth (make_fixnum (2), edges))
 26955                      - XFIXNUM (Fnth (make_fixnum (0), edges)));
 26956         }
 26957 
 26958       if (p)
 26959         f->left_pos = (FRAME_PIXEL_WIDTH (p) - width - 2 * f->border_width
 26960                        + f->left_pos);
 26961       else
 26962         f->left_pos = (x_display_pixel_width (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f))
 26963                        - width + f->left_pos);
 26964 
 26965     }
 26966 
 26967   if ((flags & YNegative) && (f->top_pos <= 0))
 26968     {
 26969       int height = FRAME_PIXEL_HEIGHT (f);
 26970 
 26971 #if defined USE_X_TOOLKIT && defined USE_MOTIF
 26972       /* Something is fishy here.  When using Motif, starting Emacs with
 26973          `-g -0-0', the frame appears too low by a few pixels.
 26974 
 26975          This seems to be so because initially, while Emacs is starting,
 26976          the column widget's height and the frame's pixel height are
 26977          different.  The column widget's height is the right one.  In
 26978          later invocations, when Emacs is up, the frame's pixel height
 26979          is right, though.
 26980 
 26981          It's not obvious where the initial small difference comes from.
 26982          2000-12-01, gerd.  */
 26983 
 26984       XtVaGetValues (f->output_data.x->column_widget, XtNheight, &height, NULL);
 26985 #endif
 26986 
 26987       if (f->output_data.x->has_been_visible && !p)
 26988         {
 26989           Lisp_Object frame;
 26990           Lisp_Object edges = Qnil;
 26991 
 26992           XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 26993           if (NILP (edges))
 26994             edges = Fx_frame_edges (frame, Qouter_edges);
 26995           if (!NILP (edges))
 26996             height = (XFIXNUM (Fnth (make_fixnum (3), edges))
 26997                       - XFIXNUM (Fnth (make_fixnum (1), edges)));
 26998         }
 26999 
 27000       if (p)
 27001         f->top_pos = (FRAME_PIXEL_HEIGHT (p) - height - 2 * f->border_width
 27002                        + f->top_pos);
 27003       else
 27004         f->top_pos = (x_display_pixel_height (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f))
 27005                       - height + f->top_pos);
 27006   }
 27007 
 27008   /* The left_pos and top_pos
 27009      are now relative to the top and left screen edges,
 27010      so the flags should correspond.  */
 27011   f->size_hint_flags &= ~ (XNegative | YNegative);
 27012 }
 27013 
 27014 /* CHANGE_GRAVITY is 1 when calling from Fset_frame_position,
 27015    to really change the position, and 0 when calling from
 27016    x_make_frame_visible (in that case, XOFF and YOFF are the current
 27017    position values).  It is -1 when calling from gui_set_frame_parameters,
 27018    which means, do adjust for borders but don't change the gravity.  */
 27019 
 27020 static void
 27021 x_set_offset (struct frame *f, int xoff, int yoff, int change_gravity)
 27022 {
 27023   int modified_top, modified_left;
 27024 #ifdef USE_GTK
 27025   int scale = xg_get_scale (f);
 27026 #endif
 27027 
 27028   if (change_gravity > 0)
 27029     {
 27030       f->top_pos = yoff;
 27031       f->left_pos = xoff;
 27032       f->size_hint_flags &= ~ (XNegative | YNegative);
 27033       if (xoff < 0)
 27034         f->size_hint_flags |= XNegative;
 27035       if (yoff < 0)
 27036         f->size_hint_flags |= YNegative;
 27037       f->win_gravity = NorthWestGravity;
 27038     }
 27039 
 27040   x_calc_absolute_position (f);
 27041 
 27042   block_input ();
 27043   x_wm_set_size_hint (f, 0, false);
 27044 
 27045 #ifdef USE_GTK
 27046   if (x_gtk_use_window_move)
 27047     {
 27048       /* When a position change was requested and the outer GTK widget
 27049          has been realized already, leave it to gtk_window_move to
 27050          DTRT and return.  Used for Bug#25851 and Bug#25943.  Convert
 27051          from X pixels to GTK scaled pixels.  */
 27052       if (change_gravity != 0 && FRAME_GTK_OUTER_WIDGET (f))
 27053         gtk_window_move (GTK_WINDOW (FRAME_GTK_OUTER_WIDGET (f)),
 27054                          f->left_pos / scale, f->top_pos / scale);
 27055       unblock_input ();
 27056       return;
 27057     }
 27058 #endif /* USE_GTK */
 27059 
 27060   modified_left = f->left_pos;
 27061   modified_top = f->top_pos;
 27062 
 27063   if (change_gravity != 0 && FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f)->wm_type == X_WMTYPE_A)
 27064     {
 27065       /* Some WMs (twm, wmaker at least) has an offset that is smaller
 27066          than the WM decorations.  So we use the calculated offset instead
 27067          of the WM decoration sizes here (x/y_pixels_outer_diff).  */
 27068       modified_left += FRAME_X_OUTPUT (f)->move_offset_left;
 27069       modified_top += FRAME_X_OUTPUT (f)->move_offset_top;
 27070     }
 27071 
 27072 #ifdef USE_GTK
 27073   /* Make sure we adjust for possible scaling.  */
 27074   gtk_window_move (GTK_WINDOW (FRAME_GTK_OUTER_WIDGET (f)),
 27075                    modified_left / scale, modified_top / scale);
 27076 #else
 27077   XMoveWindow (FRAME_X_DISPLAY (f), FRAME_OUTER_WINDOW (f),
 27078                modified_left, modified_top);
 27079 #endif
 27080 
 27081   /* The following code is too slow over a latent network
 27082      connection.  */
 27083   if (NILP (Vx_lax_frame_positioning))
 27084     {
 27085       /* 'x_sync_with_move' is too costly for dragging child frames.  */
 27086       if (!FRAME_PARENT_FRAME (f)
 27087           /* If no window manager exists, just calling XSync will be
 27088              sufficient to ensure that the window geometry has been
 27089              updated.  */
 27090           && NILP (Vx_no_window_manager))
 27091         {
 27092           x_sync_with_move (f, f->left_pos, f->top_pos,
 27093                             FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f)->wm_type == X_WMTYPE_UNKNOWN);
 27094 
 27095           /* change_gravity is non-zero when this function is called from Lisp to
 27096              programmatically move a frame.  In that case, we call
 27097              x_check_expected_move to discover if we have a "Type A" or "Type B"
 27098              window manager, and, for a "Type A" window manager, adjust the position
 27099              of the frame.
 27100 
 27101              We call x_check_expected_move if a programmatic move occurred, and
 27102              either the window manager type (A/B) is unknown or it is Type A but we
 27103              need to compute the top/left offset adjustment for this frame.  */
 27104 
 27105           if (change_gravity != 0
 27106               && (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f)->wm_type == X_WMTYPE_UNKNOWN
 27107                   || (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f)->wm_type == X_WMTYPE_A
 27108                       && (FRAME_X_OUTPUT (f)->move_offset_left == 0
 27109                           && FRAME_X_OUTPUT (f)->move_offset_top == 0))))
 27110             x_check_expected_move (f, modified_left, modified_top);
 27111         }
 27112       /* Instead, just wait for the last ConfigureWindow request to
 27113          complete.  No window manager is involved when moving child
 27114          frames.  */
 27115       else
 27116         XSync (FRAME_X_DISPLAY (f), False);
 27117     }
 27118 
 27119   unblock_input ();
 27120 }
 27121 
 27122 static Window
 27123 x_get_wm_check_window (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo)
 27124 {
 27125   Window result;
 27126   unsigned char *tmp_data = NULL;
 27127   int rc, actual_format;
 27128   unsigned long actual_size, bytes_remaining;
 27129   Atom actual_type;
 27130 
 27131   rc = XGetWindowProperty (dpyinfo->display, dpyinfo->root_window,
 27132                            dpyinfo->Xatom_net_supporting_wm_check,
 27133                            0, 1, False, XA_WINDOW, &actual_type,
 27134                            &actual_format, &actual_size,
 27135                            &bytes_remaining, &tmp_data);
 27136 
 27137   if (rc != Success || actual_type != XA_WINDOW
 27138       || actual_format != 32 || actual_size != 1)
 27139     {
 27140       if (tmp_data)
 27141         XFree (tmp_data);
 27142 
 27143       return None;
 27144     }
 27145 
 27146   result = *(Window *) tmp_data;
 27147   XFree (tmp_data);
 27148 
 27149   return result;
 27150 }
 27151 
 27152 /* Return true if _NET_SUPPORTING_WM_CHECK window exists and _NET_SUPPORTED
 27153    on the root window for frame F contains ATOMNAME.
 27154    This is how a WM check shall be done according to the Window Manager
 27155    Specification/Extended Window Manager Hints at
 27156    https://freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/wm-spec/.  */
 27157 
 27158 bool
 27159 x_wm_supports_1 (struct x_display_info *dpyinfo, Atom want_atom)
 27160 {
 27161   Atom actual_type;
 27162   unsigned long actual_size, bytes_remaining;
 27163   int i, rc, actual_format;
 27164   bool ret;
 27165   Window wmcheck_window;
 27166   Window target_window = dpyinfo->root_window;
 27167   int max_len = 65536;
 27168   Display *dpy = dpyinfo->display;
 27169   unsigned char *tmp_data = NULL;
 27170   Atom target_type = XA_WINDOW;
 27171 
 27172   /* The user says there's no window manager, so take him up on
 27173      it.  */
 27174   if (!NILP (Vx_no_window_manager))
 27175     return false;
 27176 
 27177   /* If the window system says Emacs is untrusted, there will be no
 27178      way to send any information to the window manager, making any
 27179      hints useless.  */
 27180   if (dpyinfo->untrusted)
 27181     return false;
 27182 
 27183   block_input ();
 27184 
 27185   x_catch_errors (dpy);
 27186 
 27187   wmcheck_window = dpyinfo->net_supported_window;
 27188 
 27189   if (wmcheck_window == None)
 27190     wmcheck_window = x_get_wm_check_window (dpyinfo);
 27191 
 27192   if (!x_special_window_exists_p (dpyinfo, wmcheck_window))
 27193     {
 27194       if (dpyinfo->net_supported_window != None)
 27195         {
 27196           dpyinfo->net_supported_window = None;
 27197           wmcheck_window = x_get_wm_check_window (dpyinfo);
 27198 
 27199           if (!x_special_window_exists_p (dpyinfo, wmcheck_window))
 27200             {
 27201               x_uncatch_errors ();
 27202               unblock_input ();
 27203               return false;
 27204             }
 27205         }
 27206       else
 27207         {
 27208           x_uncatch_errors ();
 27209           unblock_input ();
 27210           return false;
 27211         }
 27212     }
 27213 
 27214   if (dpyinfo->net_supported_window != wmcheck_window)
 27215     {
 27216       /* Window changed, reload atoms */
 27217       if (dpyinfo->net_supported_atoms != NULL)
 27218         XFree (dpyinfo->net_supported_atoms);
 27219       dpyinfo->net_supported_atoms = NULL;
 27220       dpyinfo->nr_net_supported_atoms = 0;
 27221       dpyinfo->net_supported_window = 0;
 27222 
 27223       target_type = XA_ATOM;
 27224       tmp_data = NULL;
 27225       rc = XGetWindowProperty (dpy, target_window,
 27226                                dpyinfo->Xatom_net_supported,
 27227                                0, max_len, False, target_type,
 27228                                &actual_type, &actual_format, &actual_size,
 27229                                &bytes_remaining, &tmp_data);
 27230 
 27231       if (rc != Success || actual_type != XA_ATOM || x_had_errors_p (dpy))
 27232         {
 27233           if (tmp_data)
 27234             XFree (tmp_data);
 27235           x_uncatch_errors ();
 27236           unblock_input ();
 27237           return false;
 27238         }
 27239 
 27240       dpyinfo->net_supported_atoms = (Atom *) tmp_data;
 27241       dpyinfo->nr_net_supported_atoms = actual_size;
 27242       dpyinfo->net_supported_window = wmcheck_window;
 27243     }
 27244 
 27245   ret = false;
 27246 
 27247   for (i = 0; !ret && i < dpyinfo->nr_net_supported_atoms; ++i)
 27248     ret = dpyinfo->net_supported_atoms[i] == want_atom;
 27249 
 27250   x_uncatch_errors ();
 27251   unblock_input ();
 27252 
 27253   return ret;
 27254 }
 27255 
 27256 bool
 27257 x_wm_supports (struct frame *f, Atom want_atom)
 27258 {
 27259   return x_wm_supports_1 (FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f),
 27260                           want_atom);
 27261 }
 27262 
 27263 static void
 27264 set_wm_state (Lisp_Object frame, bool add, Atom atom, Atom value)
 27265 {
 27266   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo;
 27267   XEvent msg;
 27268 
 27269   dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (XFRAME (frame));
 27270   msg.xclient.type = ClientMessage;
 27271   msg.xclient.window = FRAME_OUTER_WINDOW (XFRAME (frame));
 27272   msg.xclient.message_type = dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state;
 27273   msg.xclient.format = 32;
 27274 
 27275   msg.xclient.data.l[0] = add ? 1 : 0;
 27276   msg.xclient.data.l[1] = atom;
 27277   msg.xclient.data.l[2] = value;
 27278   msg.xclient.data.l[3] = 1; /* Source indication.  */
 27279   msg.xclient.data.l[4] = 0;
 27280 
 27281   block_input ();
 27282   XSendEvent (dpyinfo->display, dpyinfo->root_window,
 27283               False, (SubstructureRedirectMask
 27284                       | SubstructureNotifyMask), &msg);
 27285   unblock_input ();
 27286 }
 27287 
 27288 void
 27289 x_set_sticky (struct frame *f, Lisp_Object new_value, Lisp_Object old_value)
 27290 {
 27291   Lisp_Object frame;
 27292   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f);
 27293 
 27294   XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 27295 
 27296   set_wm_state (frame, !NILP (new_value),
 27297                 dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_sticky, None);
 27298 }
 27299 
 27300 void
 27301 x_set_shaded (struct frame *f, Lisp_Object new_value, Lisp_Object old_value)
 27302 {
 27303   Lisp_Object frame;
 27304   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f);
 27305 
 27306   XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 27307 
 27308   set_wm_state (frame, !NILP (new_value),
 27309                 dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_shaded, None);
 27310 }
 27311 
 27312 /**
 27313  * x_set_skip_taskbar:
 27314  *
 27315  * Set frame F's `skip-taskbar' parameter.  If non-nil, this should
 27316  * remove F's icon from the taskbar associated with the display of F's
 27317  * window-system window and inhibit switching to F's window via
 27318  * <Alt>-<TAB>.  If nil, lift these restrictions.
 27319  *
 27320  * Some window managers may not honor this parameter.
 27321  */
 27322 void
 27323 x_set_skip_taskbar (struct frame *f, Lisp_Object new_value, Lisp_Object old_value)
 27324 {
 27325   if (!EQ (new_value, old_value))
 27326     {
 27327 #ifdef USE_GTK
 27328       xg_set_skip_taskbar (f, new_value);
 27329 #else
 27330       Lisp_Object frame;
 27331       struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f);
 27332 
 27333       XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 27334       set_wm_state (frame, !NILP (new_value),
 27335                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_skip_taskbar, None);
 27336 #endif /* USE_GTK */
 27337       FRAME_SKIP_TASKBAR (f) = !NILP (new_value);
 27338     }
 27339 }
 27340 
 27341 /**
 27342  * x_set_z_group:
 27343  *
 27344  * Set frame F's `z-group' parameter.  If `above', F's window-system
 27345  * window is displayed above all windows that do not have the `above'
 27346  * property set.  If nil, F's window is shown below all windows that
 27347  * have the `above' property set and above all windows that have the
 27348  * `below' property set.  If `below', F's window is displayed below all
 27349  * windows that do not have the `below' property set.
 27350  *
 27351  * Some window managers may not honor this parameter.
 27352  *
 27353  * Internally, this function also handles a value 'above-suspended'.
 27354  * That value is used to temporarily remove F from the 'above' group
 27355  * to make sure that it does not obscure a menu currently popped up.
 27356  */
 27357 void
 27358 x_set_z_group (struct frame *f, Lisp_Object new_value, Lisp_Object old_value)
 27359 {
 27360   /* We don't care about old_value.  The window manager might have
 27361      reset the value without telling us.  */
 27362   Lisp_Object frame;
 27363   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f);
 27364 
 27365   XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 27366 
 27367   if (NILP (new_value))
 27368     {
 27369       set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27370                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_above, None);
 27371       set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27372                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_below, None);
 27373       FRAME_Z_GROUP (f) = z_group_none;
 27374     }
 27375   else if (EQ (new_value, Qabove))
 27376     {
 27377       set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27378                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_above, None);
 27379       set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27380                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_below, None);
 27381       FRAME_Z_GROUP (f) = z_group_above;
 27382     }
 27383   else if (EQ (new_value, Qbelow))
 27384     {
 27385       set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27386                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_above, None);
 27387       set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27388                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_below, None);
 27389       FRAME_Z_GROUP (f) = z_group_below;
 27390     }
 27391   else if (EQ (new_value, Qabove_suspended))
 27392     {
 27393       set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27394                     dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_above, None);
 27395       FRAME_Z_GROUP (f) = z_group_above_suspended;
 27396     }
 27397   else
 27398     error ("Invalid z-group specification");
 27399 }
 27400 
 27401 
 27402 /* Return the current _NET_WM_STATE.
 27403    SIZE_STATE is set to one of the FULLSCREEN_* values.
 27404    Set *STICKY to the sticky state.
 27405 
 27406    Return true iff we are not hidden.  */
 27407 
 27408 static bool
 27409 x_get_current_wm_state (struct frame *f,
 27410                         Window window,
 27411                         int *size_state,
 27412                         bool *sticky,
 27413                         bool *shaded)
 27414 {
 27415   unsigned long actual_size;
 27416   int i;
 27417   bool is_hidden = false;
 27418   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f);
 27419   long max_len = 65536;
 27420   Atom target_type = XA_ATOM;
 27421   /* If XCB is available, we can avoid three XSync calls.  */
 27422 #ifdef USE_XCB
 27423   xcb_get_property_cookie_t prop_cookie;
 27424   xcb_get_property_reply_t *prop;
 27425   typedef xcb_atom_t reply_data_object;
 27426 #else
 27427   Display *dpy = FRAME_X_DISPLAY (f);
 27428   unsigned long bytes_remaining;
 27429   int rc, actual_format;
 27430   Atom actual_type;
 27431   unsigned char *tmp_data = NULL;
 27432   typedef Atom reply_data_object;
 27433 #endif
 27434   reply_data_object *reply_data;
 27435 # if defined GCC_LINT || defined lint
 27436   reply_data_object reply_data_dummy;
 27437   reply_data = &reply_data_dummy;
 27438 # endif
 27439 
 27440   *sticky = false;
 27441   *size_state = FULLSCREEN_NONE;
 27442   *shaded = false;
 27443 
 27444   block_input ();
 27445 
 27446 #ifdef USE_XCB
 27447   prop_cookie = xcb_get_property (dpyinfo->xcb_connection, 0, window,
 27448                                   dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state,
 27449                                   target_type, 0, max_len);
 27450   prop = xcb_get_property_reply (dpyinfo->xcb_connection, prop_cookie, NULL);
 27451   if (prop && prop->type == target_type)
 27452     {
 27453       int actual_bytes = xcb_get_property_value_length (prop);
 27454       eassume (0 <= actual_bytes);
 27455       actual_size = actual_bytes / sizeof *reply_data;
 27456       reply_data = xcb_get_property_value (prop);
 27457     }
 27458   else
 27459     {
 27460       actual_size = 0;
 27461       is_hidden = FRAME_ICONIFIED_P (f);
 27462     }
 27463 #else
 27464   x_catch_errors (dpy);
 27465   rc = XGetWindowProperty (dpy, window, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state,
 27466                            0, max_len, False, target_type,
 27467                            &actual_type, &actual_format, &actual_size,
 27468                            &bytes_remaining, &tmp_data);
 27469 
 27470   if (rc == Success && actual_type == target_type && ! x_had_errors_p (dpy))
 27471     reply_data = (Atom *) tmp_data;
 27472   else
 27473     {
 27474       actual_size = 0;
 27475       is_hidden = FRAME_ICONIFIED_P (f);
 27476     }
 27477 
 27478   x_uncatch_errors ();
 27479 #endif
 27480 
 27481   for (i = 0; i < actual_size; ++i)
 27482     {
 27483       Atom a = reply_data[i];
 27484       if (a == dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_hidden)
 27485         is_hidden = true;
 27486       else if (a == dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz)
 27487         {
 27488           if (*size_state == FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT)
 27489             *size_state = FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED;
 27490           else
 27491             *size_state = FULLSCREEN_WIDTH;
 27492         }
 27493       else if (a == dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert)
 27494         {
 27495           if (*size_state == FULLSCREEN_WIDTH)
 27496             *size_state = FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED;
 27497           else
 27498             *size_state = FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT;
 27499         }
 27500       else if (a == dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen)
 27501         *size_state = FULLSCREEN_BOTH;
 27502       else if (a == dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_sticky)
 27503         *sticky = true;
 27504       else if (a == dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_shaded)
 27505         *shaded = true;
 27506     }
 27507 
 27508 #ifdef USE_XCB
 27509   free (prop);
 27510 #else
 27511   if (tmp_data) XFree (tmp_data);
 27512 #endif
 27513 
 27514   unblock_input ();
 27515   return ! is_hidden;
 27516 }
 27517 
 27518 /* Do fullscreen as specified in extended window manager hints */
 27519 
 27520 static bool
 27521 do_ewmh_fullscreen (struct frame *f)
 27522 {
 27523   struct x_display_info *dpyinfo = FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f);
 27524   bool have_net_atom = x_wm_supports (f, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state);
 27525   int cur;
 27526   bool dummy;
 27527 
 27528   x_get_current_wm_state (f, FRAME_OUTER_WINDOW (f), &cur, &dummy, &dummy);
 27529 
 27530   /* Some window managers don't say they support _NET_WM_STATE, but they do say
 27531      they support _NET_WM_STATE_FULLSCREEN.  Try that also.  */
 27532   if (!have_net_atom)
 27533     have_net_atom = x_wm_supports (f, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen);
 27534 
 27535   if (have_net_atom && cur != f->want_fullscreen)
 27536     {
 27537       Lisp_Object frame;
 27538 
 27539       XSETFRAME (frame, f);
 27540 
 27541       /* Keep number of calls to set_wm_state as low as possible.
 27542          Some window managers, or possible Gtk+, hangs when too many
 27543          are sent at once.  */
 27544       switch (f->want_fullscreen)
 27545         {
 27546         case FULLSCREEN_BOTH:
 27547           if (cur != FULLSCREEN_BOTH)
 27548             set_wm_state (frame, true, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen,
 27549                           None);
 27550           break;
 27551         case FULLSCREEN_WIDTH:
 27552           if (x_frame_normalize_before_maximize && cur == FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED)
 27553             {
 27554               set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27555                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27556                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27557               set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27558                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz, None);
 27559             }
 27560           else
 27561             {
 27562               if (cur == FULLSCREEN_BOTH || cur == FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT
 27563                   || cur == FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED)
 27564                 set_wm_state (frame, false, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen,
 27565                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27566               if (cur != FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED || x_frame_normalize_before_maximize)
 27567                 set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27568                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz, None);
 27569             }
 27570           break;
 27571         case FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT:
 27572           if (x_frame_normalize_before_maximize && cur == FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED)
 27573             {
 27574               set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27575                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27576                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27577               set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27578                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert, None);
 27579             }
 27580           else
 27581             {
 27582               if (cur == FULLSCREEN_BOTH || cur == FULLSCREEN_WIDTH
 27583                   || cur == FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED)
 27584                 set_wm_state (frame, false, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen,
 27585                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz);
 27586               if (cur != FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED || x_frame_normalize_before_maximize)
 27587                 set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27588                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert, None);
 27589             }
 27590           break;
 27591         case FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED:
 27592           if (x_frame_normalize_before_maximize && cur == FULLSCREEN_BOTH)
 27593             {
 27594               set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27595                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen, None);
 27596               set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27597                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27598                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27599             }
 27600           else if (x_frame_normalize_before_maximize && cur == FULLSCREEN_WIDTH)
 27601             {
 27602               set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27603                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz, None);
 27604               set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27605                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27606                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27607             }
 27608           else if (x_frame_normalize_before_maximize && cur == FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT)
 27609             {
 27610               set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27611                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert, None);
 27612               set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27613                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27614                             dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27615             }
 27616           else
 27617             {
 27618               if (cur == FULLSCREEN_BOTH)
 27619                 set_wm_state (frame, false, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen,
 27620                               None);
 27621               else if (cur == FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT)
 27622                 set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27623                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz, None);
 27624               else if (cur == FULLSCREEN_WIDTH)
 27625                 set_wm_state (frame, true, None,
 27626                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27627               else
 27628                 set_wm_state (frame, true,
 27629                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27630                               dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27631             }
 27632           break;
 27633         case FULLSCREEN_NONE:
 27634           if (cur == FULLSCREEN_BOTH)
 27635             set_wm_state (frame, false, dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_fullscreen,
 27636                           None);
 27637           else
 27638             set_wm_state (frame, false,
 27639                           dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_horz,
 27640                           dpyinfo->Xatom_net_wm_state_maximized_vert);
 27641         }
 27642 
 27643       f->want_fullscreen = FULLSCREEN_NONE;
 27644 
 27645     }
 27646 
 27647   return have_net_atom;
 27648 }
 27649 
 27650 static void
 27651 XTfullscreen_hook (struct frame *f)
 27652 {
 27653   if (!FRAME_VISIBLE_P (f))
 27654     return;
 27655 
 27656   block_input ();
 27657   x_check_fullscreen (f);
 27658   unblock_input ();
 27659 }
 27660 
 27661 
 27662 static bool
 27663 x_handle_net_wm_state (struct frame *f, const XPropertyEvent *event)
 27664 {
 27665   int value = FULLSCREEN_NONE;
 27666   Lisp_Object lval;
 27667   bool sticky = false, shaded = false;
 27668   bool not_hidden = x_get_current_wm_state (f, event->window,
 27669                                             &value, &sticky,
 27670                                             &shaded);
 27671 
 27672   lval = Qnil;
 27673   switch (value)
 27674     {
 27675     case FULLSCREEN_WIDTH:
 27676       lval = Qfullwidth;
 27677       break;
 27678     case FULLSCREEN_HEIGHT:
 27679       lval = Qfullheight;
 27680       break;
 27681     case FULLSCREEN_BOTH:
 27682       lval = Qfullboth;
 27683       break;
 27684     case FULLSCREEN_MAXIMIZED:
 27685       lval = Qmaximized;
 27686       break;
 27687     }
 27688 
 27689   store_frame_param (f, Qfullscreen, lval);
 27690   store_frame_param (f, Qsticky, sticky ? Qt : Qnil);
 27691   store_frame_param (f, Qshaded, shaded ? Qt : Qnil);
 27692 
 27693   return not_hidden;
 27694 }
 27695 
 27696 /* Check if we need to resize the frame due to a fullscreen request.
 27697    If so needed, resize the frame. */
 27698 static void
 27699 x_check_fullscreen (struct frame *f)
 27700 {
 27701   Lisp_Object lval = Qnil;
 27702 
 27703   if (do_ewmh_fullscreen (f))
 27704     return;
 27705 
 27706   if (f->output_data.x->parent_desc != FRAME_DISPLAY_INFO (f)->root_window)
 27707     return; /* Only fullscreen without WM or with EWM hints (above). */
 27708 
 27709   /* Setting fullscreen to nil doesn't do anything.  We could save the
 27710      last non-fullscreen size and restore it, but it seems like a
 27711      lot of work for this unusual case (no window manager running).  */
 27712 
 27713   if (f->want_fullscreen != FULLSCREEN_NONE)
 27714     {
 27715       int width = FRAME_PIXEL_WIDTH (f), height = FRAME_PIXEL_HEIGHT (f);
